Assignment Workflow

How Assignment Submission Works

In this course, you will submit all assignments through GitHub. This mirrors real-world data science workflows where version control is essential.

We streamline this process using GitHub Classroom and RStudio‚Äôs built-in tools. You essentially never need to open the terminal.

Step-by-Step Guide

Step 1: Accept the Assignment

  1. Click the GitHub Classroom link provided on Moodle/Course Page.
  2. GitHub will automatically create a private repository for you (e.g., assignment-1-yourname).
  3. Copy the URL of this new repository from your browser address bar.
    • It should look like: https://github.com/MA22019/assignment-1-yourname

Step 2: Clone into RStudio

Do not download a ZIP file. We will connect RStudio directly to the cloud.

ImportantWHERE TO SAVE? (Critical)

Do NOT save this project in OneDrive, Dropbox, or Google Drive. Cloud sync services corrupt Git repositories.

Recommendation: Use your University H: Drive (Network mapped drive). üëâ Read the H: Drive Setup/Map Guide

  1. Open RStudio.
  2. Go to File > New Project...
  3. Choose Version Control (the 3rd option).
  4. Choose Git (the 1st option).
  5. Paste the Repository URL you copied in Step 1.
  6. Click Create Project.

Result: RStudio will download your assignment files and open them automatically.

Step 3: The ‚ÄúEdit - Commit‚Äù Loop

You should save your work to the ‚Äúcloud‚Äù (GitHub) frequently. Think of this as a super-charged ‚ÄúSave‚Äù button.

The Workflow:

  1. Edit: Work on your .qmd file. Write code, analysis, and answers.
  2. Render: Click ‚ÄúRender‚Äù to ensure your code runs and produces the HTML output.
  3. Stage (The Checkbox):
    • Go to the Git Pane in RStudio (usually top-right).
    • Check the Staged box next to the files you changed (e.g., assignment.qmd).
  4. Commit (The Snapshot):
    • Click the Commit button in the Git Pane.
    • Write a message in the box: ‚ÄúCompleted Question 1 data cleaning‚Äù.
    • Click Commit.
ImportantCommit at Least 3 Times!

We expect to see a progression of work in your commits. This helps us: - Verify the work is yours - Give partial credit if something breaks - Provide better feedback

Step 4: Submit (Push)

Your ‚ÄúCommits‚Äù are currently only saved on your local computer. To submit them to us, you must Push.

  1. In the Git Pane, look for the Green Up Arrow (Push).
  2. Click it.
  3. Wait for the message: ‚ÄúHEAD -> main‚Ä¶ set up to track remote branch‚Ä¶‚Äù

Verification: Go back to your GitHub repository page in your browser and refresh. You should see your latest commit message and updated files.

Assignment Repository Structure

Each assignment repository will contain:

assignment-name/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md           # Instructions overview
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ assignment.qmd      # Main file you'll edit
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ data/               # Datasets for the assignment
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ dataset.csv
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ .gitignore          # Files to ignore
NoteLarge Datasets

Some assignments require large data files (> 25 MB). These will be available on Moodle. Download and place them in the data/ folder inside your project before running the code.

What Gets Graded?

1. Content (80%)

What We Look At Why It Matters
Your .qmd file Your code and written answers
Rendered output Does your code run correctly?
Accuracy Are your answers correct?
Completeness Did you attempt all questions?

2. Workflow Points (20%) - ‚ÄúThe 3-Commit Rule‚Äù

We grade your professional habits.

Requirement: You must commit at least 3 times as you work through the assignment.

Requirement Points What We Check
Minimum 3 commits 10% We look at your commit history
Final files in repo 5% Both .qmd and rendered output on GitHub
Organization 5% Clean repo, meaningful commit messages

Why do we require multiple commits? 1. Proves progression: Shows you worked incrementally, not all at once. 2. Enables recovery: If something breaks, you have earlier working versions. 3. Mirrors industry: Professional developers commit frequently.

Deadlines and Late Policy

WarningImportant!
  • Deadline: The state of your GitHub repository at the deadline time
  • Late submissions: 10% penalty per day, up to 3 days
  • After 3 days: No submissions accepted without prior arrangement

How to Check Your Submission

  1. Go to github.com
  2. Navigate to your assignment repository
  3. Verify:
    • ‚úÖ Your .qmd file is there and up to date
    • ‚úÖ All files are committed
    • ‚úÖ Last commit time is before the deadline

Getting Your Own Copy Started

If you want to work on something not from an assignment invite link:

Creating a New Repository

  1. Go to github.com/new
  2. Name your repository
  3. Select ‚ÄúAdd a README file‚Äù
  4. Click ‚ÄúCreate repository‚Äù
  5. Follow the Clone steps above to bring it into RStudio.

Collaboration on Group Projects

For group projects, you‚Äôll work together in a shared repository:

Rules for Group Work

  1. Pull before you start working: Use the Blue Down Arrow (Pull) in the Git Pane.
  2. Communicate: Tell teammates what you‚Äôre working on.
  3. Commit frequently: Smaller commits are easier to merge.
  4. Push when done: Don‚Äôt leave changes on your computer.

Troubleshooting

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see the Git Pane in RStudio‚Äù

  • Did you skip Step 2? You must create a New Project > Version Control. You cannot just ‚ÄúOpen File‚Äù.
  • Try Tools > Project Options > Git/SVN and ensure ‚ÄúVersion control system‚Äù is set to ‚ÄúGit‚Äù.

‚ÄúPush Failed‚Äù (Login Errors)

  • GitHub no longer accepts regular passwords.
  • If RStudio asks for a username/password:
    • Username: Your GitHub username.
    • Password: You must use a Personal Access Token (PAT).
    • See the Setup Guide/Git Guide for generating a PAT.

‚ÄúMerge Conflict‚Äù

  • This rarely happens in individual assignments unless you edit files on two different computers.
  • If you see <<<<<<< HEAD, ask a TA for help immediately. Don‚Äôt panic!
